TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants were born in DATE and DATE respectively and live in GPE .

CARDINAL . PERSON left GPE in DATE , allegedly to flee from religious persecution . For a short time he remained in GPE and in GPE , and DATE arrived in GPE . Initially he sought asylum . CARDINAL . On DATE Mr Raza appealed to the Minister of ORG against the order for his expulsion ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . He argued that it was unlawful , because he resided legally in GPE , lived with his wife and had never committed any offence . On DATE the Minister rejected the appeal , saying that there existed information that Mr Raza had been involved in human trafficking . He went on to specify that in cases of expulsion on national security or public order grounds it was not open to the administrative authorities to take into account extraneous considerations ; if the necessary prerequisites were in place , the authorities were bound to take the measure in question .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date in DATE PERSON sought judicial review of the expulsion order by ORG . He additionally asked the court to stay the order ’s enforcement . He asserted , inter alia , that he had been married to a NORP national for DATE and had never engaged in any unlawful activities . CARDINAL . In a decision of DATE the court found the application admissible , holding that the bar to judicial review set out in section PERSON ) of the DATE LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) was contrary to the Convention and was thus to be disregarded . It relied on this ORG ’s judgment in the case of PERSON v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , DATE ) . In any event , PERSON had not put forward any arguments capable of persuading the court that the order should be stayed .
CARDINAL . Mr Raza did not appeal against the court ’s refusal to stay the enforcement of the expulsion order .

CARDINAL . NORP The court held a nonpublic hearing on CARDINAL DATE . It admitted in evidence the administrative case file with the materials leading to the expulsion order , allowed PERSON to inspect them , and gave him leave to adduce evidence in support of his allegations .
CARDINAL . In view of amendments to the DATE LAW making expulsion orders subject to review by ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , on DATE ORG transferred the case to ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG heard the case on DATE . PERSON , who was legally represented , did not adduce evidence . The public prosecutor , who took part in the proceedings ex officio , argued that since the law specifically provided that no reasons were to be given for expulsion orders , the court was not competent to review the substantive lawfulness of the order , but only whether the procedure had been followed .

Nor did it scrutinise the facts underlying the decision to expel PERSON , or have before it the full text of the proposal for his expulsion , but merely a short excerpt from it , drawn up by the authorities specifically for the purposes of the judicial review proceedings .

CARDINAL . The applicants were not able to provide a copy of ORG judgment because the case is classified and neither they nor their counsel are allowed to make copies of any of the materials in the case file , including that judgment . CARDINAL . On an unspecified date in DATE PERSON sought judicial review of the order for his placement in a detention facility ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . CARDINAL . Following an appeal by ORG , on DATE ( реш. № DATE от CARDINAL юни DATE г. по адм. д. № DATE г. , PERSON , III о. ) ORG annulled that judgment and discontinued the proceedings . It was therefore not subject to judicial review by itself .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants sought judicial review of the decision of CARDINAL DATE turning down PERSON application for release ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . On DATE ORG declared PERSON application inadmissible , because she was not directly affected by the order , but found PERSON application admissible and wellfounded . It noted that the immigration authorities had sent CARDINAL letters to the consular department of ORG with requests for assistance in the process of securing a travel document for PERSON , but that no reply had been received . It went on to say that , in view of the difficulties in carrying out the expulsion , the authorities should have reconsidered whether or not Mr PERSON ’s detention continued to be justified . In situations where they had discretion , the authorities had to assess whether or not the impugned measures interfered disproportionately with the individual ’s rights and , whenever possible , opt for the option that was less onerous for the individual , in line with the principle of proportionality . The exercise of such discretion was subject to judicial review . Instead of keeping PERSON in custody , the authorities could have placed him under an obligation to report DATE to his local police station . In choosing between those alternatives , they had to take account of the length of the detention . If it exceeded DATE , it became an arbitrary deprivation of liberty , contrary to LAW ( f ) of the LAW . The inordinate amount of time spent by PERSON in custody , owing to the lack of effective measures for his expulsion , had negated the lawfulness of his deprivation of liberty . As the authorities had not taken those matters into account , they had made an unlawful decision . The court therefore quashed the refusal to release PERSON PERSON and instructed the authorities to reconsider the matter in line with its reasoning .

It held that the Director did not have standing to appeal , as the proceedings before the lower court had unfolded between the applicants and the immigration authorities . Moreover , since PERSON had meanwhile been released ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , the issues raised in the appeal were no longer relevant .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the DATE LAW provides that aliens who are lawfully resident in the country can not be expelled from it except under conditions and in a manner prescribed by law .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the DATE LAW provides that an alien must be expelled when his or her presence in the country creates a serious threat to national security or public order . Under section ORG ) , expulsion must be accompanied by withdrawal of the alien ’s residence permit and the imposition of a ban on entering the country . Expulsion orders are immediately enforceable ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . If deportation can not be effected immediately or needs to be postponed for legal or technical reasons , the enforcement of the expulsion order may be stayed until the relevant obstacles have been overcome ( section CARDINALb(CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , as in force until DATE , provided that orders for the expulsion of aliens on national security grounds were not subject to judicial review . Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , those orders do not indicate the factual grounds for imposing the measure .

CARDINAL . Following this ORG ’s judgment in the case of PERSON v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , DATE ) , in which it found the above provisions contrary to LAW , ORG changed its caselaw . In a number of judgments and decisions delivered in DATE it held , by reference to PERSON , that the ban on judicial review in section PERSON ) was to be disregarded as it contravened the ORG , and that expulsion orders relying on national security considerations were amenable to judicial review ( реш. № CARDINAL от CARDINAL май DATE по адм. д. № DATE г. ; реш. № CARDINAL от CARDINAL май DATE г. по адм. д. № DATE г. ; опр. № CARDINAL от CARDINAL януари DATE г. по адм. д. № DATE г. ; опр. № DATE от CARDINAL май DATE г. по адм. д. № DATE г. ; опр. № DATE от CARDINAL ноември DATE г. по адм. д. № DATE г. ; опр. № CARDINAL от DATE по адм. д. № DATE г. ; опр. № CARDINAL от DATE по адм. д. № DATE г. ; опр. № DATE от CARDINAL май DATE г. по адм. д. № DATE г. ; опр. № DATE от DATE г. по адм. д. № DATE г. ) .
CARDINAL . NORP In DATE section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) was amended and at present provides that expulsion orders may be challenged before ORG , whose judgment is final .

CARDINAL . In DATE the Act underwent a reshuffle intended to bring it into line with the requirements of Directive CARDINAL of ORG and of ORG on common standards and procedures in Member GPE for returning illegally staying thirdcountry nationals . The new version of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that when ordering expulsion or similar measures the authorities must take into account the length of time an alien has remained in GPE , his or her family status , and the existence of any family , cultural and social ties with the country of origin . It is not yet clear whether those factors should also be considered upon the expulsion of an individual on national security grounds .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the DATE Act provides that if there are impediments to a deportee ’s leaving GPE or entering the destination country , he or she is placed under an obligation to report DATE to his or her local police station .

CARDINAL . Under CARDINAL ) , as in force until DATE , aliens could , if necessary , be placed in special detention facilities pending the removal of the obstacles to their deportation . In the reform of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) that provision was amended to provide that detention was possible if an alien ’s identity was unknown , if he or she hindered the enforcement of the expulsion order , or if he or she presented a risk of absconding .

CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ( after DATE section CARDINAL ) ) , deportees are placed in detention facilities pursuant to special orders , which have to specify the need for such placement and its legal grounds and be accompanied by copies of the orders under section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . In the reform of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) a new section LOC was added , making special provision for judicial review of orders for the detention of deportees . Deportees may now seek judicial review of such orders by the competent administrative court within DATE of them being issued ( subsection CARDINAL ) . The application for judicial review does not stay their enforcement ( ibid . ) . The court must examine the application at a public hearing and rule , by means of a final judgment , not DATE after the proceedings were instituted ( subsection CARDINAL ) . In addition , DATE the head of any facility where deportees are being detained must present to the court a list of all individuals who have remained there for DATE due to problems with their removal from the country ( subsection CARDINAL ) . The court must then rule , on its own motion and by means of a final decision , on their continued detention or release ( subsection CARDINAL ) . When the court sets aside the detention order , or orders a deportee ’s release , he or she must be set free immediately ( subsection CARDINAL ) .
